metadata.titleEn: Dataset of urban impervious surface area and green space fractions in the Tibetan Plateau (2000-2020)
metadata.description:
The data sources of this dataset mainly include domestic satellite images such as HJ-1A/B, GF-1/2, ZY-3, and Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI series satellite image data. Using the domestic satellite images supplemented by Google Earth images to generate the component training sample and validation sample data of different geographical divisions. Using Google Earth Engine (GEE) to test and correct the model algorithm parameters. The normalized settlement density index (NSDI) is obtained based on random forest algorithm, Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI series satellite images and auxiliary data. The vector boundary of urban built-up area is obtained by density segmentation method after manual interactive interpretation and correction. The NSDI, vegetation coverage index and vector boundary of the Tibetan Plateau are used to produce the original data of urban impervious surface and urban green space fractions in the Tibetan Plateau. After correction and accuracy evaluation, the datasets of urban impervious surface area and green space fractions in the Tibetan Plateau from 2000 to 2020 are generated. 
The resolution of the data product is 30 m, and the coordinate system and storage format of the data files are unified. The geographic coordinate system is WGS84, the projected coordinate system is Albers, and the data storage format is GeoTIFF, the data unit is percentage (the value range is 0~10000), and the scale factor is 0.01.
In order to quantify the change of urban land cover more accurately, samples from several typical cities are selected to verify the dataset. The specific verification methods and accuracy are shown in the published results.
The data can be used to analyze and reveal the impact of land cover change and future scenario simulation on the Tibetan Plateau, to provide a scientific basis for building environmentally livable cities and improving the quality of human settlements on the Tibetan Plateau.
metadata.instructions:
The data organization structure is two levels, as follows:
Directory: component (CUISA, CUGS)
The sample of data format contained in the directory is: Component_QTP_Year.tif (e.g. CUISA_QTP_2020.tif, CUGS_QTP_2020.tif)
Component is the component information of urban land cover change, including China Urban Impervious Surface Area (CUISA) and China Urban Green Space (CUGS); Year is the data year, including 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015, 2020; QTP is the abbreviation of the Tibetan Plateau.
The data can be opened, displayed, edited, viewed, statistically analyzed, etc. using GIS software supporting *. TIF file format.

background: Global urbanization promotes social–economic development, which profoundly affects ecosystem services and environmental sustainability. Currently, urban areas accommodate 55% of the global population, contribute 75% of global gross domestic product (GDP), and produce 75% of global carbon emissions in energy use. Cities symbolize the most intensified land-use activities within coupled human–environment systems. As a result, urbanization can influence the biophysical and biochemical processes, i.e., land-cover change, surface radiation and energy changes, hydrologic processes, and materials cycles, among others, all of which affect cropland encroachments, urban heat islands, rain flood disasters, biodiversity loss, and climate change in many ways. Therefore, new knowledge about global urban land cover is essential to address urban-related issues of environmental sustainability through science–policy interfaces. As the two foundation components of urban land or built-up areas, urban impervious surface area (ISA) and green space (GS) are important for building a better urban future that is livable, comfortable, and sustainable.
research objective: To address the issue, the hierarchical architecture principle and subpixel metric method were applied to map 30 m global urban ISA and GS fractions for the years 2015 and circa 2020.
challenges: However, the current global mapping of ISA and GS is not effective enough to accurately delineate in urban areas due to the mosaicked and complex structure.
methods: We use random forest algorithms for retrieval of the Normalized Settlement Density Index and Normalized Green Space Index from Landsat images using Google Earth Engine.
dataset: The data sources were mainly Landsat OLI with a spatial resolution of 30 m. VIIRS day/night, and SRTM digital elevation model (DEM) data were also used as input parameters in the calculations to map urban ISA and GS products. Google Earth and GF-2 images were used for the accuracy assessments. Globally, a total of 37,962 samples from different urban ecoregions along urban–rural gradients with a random sampling method were acquired within the sampled cities.
findings: The correlation coefficients of global urban ISA and GS fractions were all higher than 0.9 for 2015 and circa 2020. Our results show global urban ISA and GS areas in circa 2020 were 31.19 ×10^4 km^2 and 17.16 ×10^4 km^2, respectively. The novel ISA and GS fractions product can show potential applications in assessing the effects of urbanization on climate, ecology, and urban sustainability.

background: Accurate and timely maps of urban underlying land properties at the national scale are of significance in improving habitat environment and achieving sustainable development goals. Urban impervious surface (UIS) and urban green space (UGS) are two core components for characterizing urban underlying environments. However, the UIS and UGS are often mosaicked in the urban landscape with complex structures and composites. Although six mainstream datasets on global or national urban land use and land cover products with a 30 m spatial resolution have been developed, they only provide the binary pattern or dynamic of a single urban land type, which cannot effectively delineate the quantitative components or structure of intra-urban land cover. The effects of rapid urbanization on environments have been witnessed around the world and profoundly contribute to changes in biosphere, hydrosphere and atmosphere. In China, a rapid urbanization process emerged in the 21st century, resulting in a rapid increase in urban impervious surface area (UIS). This process further triggered various urban environmental problems such as urban heat islands and urban flooding. Although many green areas have been constructed in Chinese cities recently, China has a relatively lower percentage of urban green space (UGS) than developed countries such as the United States. These urban environmental problems triggered the urgency of developing accurate urban land cover datasets with high spatial resolutions for delineating the underlying urban environments. Various land use products such as the Global Land Cover product (GlobaLand30), the University of Maryland (UMD) Land Cover Classification, Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS)-based land use and land cover products, GlobCover, and Finer Resolution Observation and Monitoring of Global Land Cover (FROM-GLC) are freely available worldwide. Most urban land products have focused on built-up land or urban area classification but cannot delineate urban land as a heterogeneous unit consisting of UIS, UGS and other fractions.
research objective: Here we propose a new mapping strategy to acquire the multitemporal and fractional information of the essential urban land cover types at a national scale through synergizing the advantage of both big data processing and human interpretation with the aid of geoknowledge. To address the above issues, we propose a synthetical strategy to utilize the advantage of both accurate urban boundary information from China’s Land Use/cover Dataset (CLUD) extracted by human–computer digitalization and the retrieval of UIS and UGS fractions through big-data processing from the GEE platform. This dataset provides a foundation for understanding urban dwellers’ environments and enhances our understanding of the impacts of urbanization on ecological services and functions, and it will also be helpful in future research and practices in urban planning and urban environmental sustainability.
challenges: There are two critical challenges in mapping urban land cover composites. Firstly, the conceptual definition of urban land or ISA in previous research is unclear; thus, the spatial extent is inconsistent, resulting in a large divergence in the statistical area of urban land. Meanwhile, the segmentation on urban–rural boundaries has not been accurate from moderate-resolution satellite images using computer-based automatic classification owing to differences in geographic conditions, social economic conditions and land policies. Secondly, the spatial heterogeneity of urban surface properties has resulted in difficulty in decomposing urban land cover types with complex surface materials at the pixel scale, which has been limited by the huge amounts of data processing and storage capacities required for a 30 m resolution.
methods: Firstly, the vector polygons of urban boundaries in 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015 and 2018 were extracted from China’s Land Use/cover Dataset (CLUD) derived from Landsat images. Secondly, the national settlement and vegetation percentages were retrieved using a sub-pixel decomposition method through a random forest algorithm using the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform. Finally, the products of China’s UIS and UGS fractions (CLUD-Urban) at a 30 m resolution were developed in 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015 and 2018. To acquire the accurate CLUD-Urban product, three steps were generally implemented according to our mapping strategy. Firstly, national urban boundaries in 2000–2018 were extracted from CLUD which was generated using a uniform technological flow and classification system in a human–computer digitalization environment. Secondly, the settlement and vegetation fractions with a 30 m resolution were retrieved using a random forest algorithm in the GEE platform. Thirdly, the UIS and UGS fractions with a 30 m resolution were mapped through overlaying the urban boundaries of CLUD with settlement and vegetation fractions, respectively.
dataset: Landsat Thematic Mapper (TM), Enhanced Thematic Mapper Plus (ETM +) and Operational Land Imager (OLI) data with path ranges of 118–149 and row ranges of 23–43 in China were selected. In mapping CLUD, Landsat TM, ETM+and OLI in each period, China–Brazil Earth Resources Satellite program (CBERS) and Huan Jing (HJ-1A and HJ-1B) satellite images in 2010 were used to generate false-color composite images with near-infrared, red and green spectral bands as red, green and blue. Image enhancement was performed to improve the visual interpretation quality. Image-to-image registration was conducted to control the image rectification errors of less than 2 pixels (60 m). CBERS-1 and Huan Jing (HJ-1A and HJ-1B) satellite images were only used in extracting the vector polygons of CLUD in 2010, which was conducted using uniform data processing with Landsat images. In the retrieval of settlement and vegetation fractions, Landsat TM, ETM+, and OLI data in each period from January to December were collected using the GEE platform. Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) digital elevation model data and the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) with a 30 m resolution were acquired as input parameters to retrieve settlement and vegetation fractions. Google Earth images in selected cities with a 0.6 m resolution were used to assess the accuracy of the CLUD-Urban product.
findings: The assessment results showed that the CLUD-Urban product has higher accuracies in urban-boundary and urban-expansion detection than other products and in addition that the accurate UIS and UGS fractions were developed in each period. The overall accuracy of urban boundaries in 2000–2018 are over 92.65 %; and the correlation coefficient (R) and root mean square errors (RMSEs) of UIS and UGS fractions are 0.91 and 0.10 (UIS) and 0.89 and 0.11 (UGS), respectively. Our result indicates that 71 % of pixels of urban land were mosaicked by the UIS and UGS within cities in 2018; a single UIS classification may highly increase the mapping uncertainty. The high spatial heterogeneity of urban underlying covers was exhibited with average fractions of 68.21 % for UIS and 22.30 % for UGS in 2018 at a national scale. The UIS and UGS increased unprecedentedly with annual rates of 1605.56 and 627.78 km2 yr−1 in 2000–2018, driven by fast urbanization. The CLUD-Urban mapping can fill the knowledge gap in understanding impacts of the UIS and UGS patterns on ecosystem services and habitat environments and is valuable for detecting the hotspots of waterlogging and improving urban greening for planning and management practices.

Verification.Question: Can the use of random forest algorithms effectively retrieve the Normalized Settlement Density Index from Landsat images?

Disjunctive.Question: Is data accuracy assessment for urban land cover datasets typically performed using Google Earth images, VIIRS data, or field surveys?

Concept Completion.Question: What data sources are used for mapping urban impervious surface area and green space fractions in this field?
Concept Completion.Answer: Landsat OLI, VIIRS day/night, SRTM digital elevation model DEM, Google Earth, GF-2 images

Concept Completion.Question: When are the urban boundaries and fractions of urban land cover types typically extracted for analysis?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to map urban impervious surface area (ISA) and green space (GS) fractions globally?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used to map urban impervious surface area (ISA) and green space (GS) fractions globally involves using random forest algorithms to retrieve the Normalized Settlement Density Index and Normalized Green Space Index from Landsat images via the Google Earth Engine platform. This method also integrates VIIRS day/night and SRTM digital elevation model (DEM) data as input parameters, along with Google Earth and GF-2 images for accuracy assessment.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in mapping urban land cover composites at a national level?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced in mapping urban land cover composites at a national level is the spatial heterogeneity of urban surface properties, which makes it difficult to decompose urban land cover types with complex surface materials at the pixel scale. This is compounded by the immense data processing and storage capacities required for a 30 m resolution.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used to map urban impervious surface area (ISA) and green space (GS) in the context of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: satellite imagery, HJ-1A/B, GF-1/2, ZY-3, Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI, Google Earth imagery, component training samples, validation samples, Normalized Settlement Density Index (NSDI), random forest algorithm, Google Earth Engine platform

Feature Specification.Question: What challenges are associated with accurately mapping urban land cover components like ISA and GS using current datasets?
Feature Specification.Answer: mosaicked and complex structure, spatial heterogeneity, significant data processing and storage capacities

Feature Specification.Question: What are the essential features and resolutions of datasets used for analyzing urban land cover changes on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: 30 m resolution, unified coordinate system, Geotiff format, WGS84 geographic coordinate system, Albers projection coordinate system, urban impervious surfaces and green space components in percentages, value range of 0 to 10000, scale factor of 0.01

Quantification.Question: How many samples were used globally from different urban ecoregions for mapping urban impervious surface area and green space fractions?
What is the correlation coefficient for the global urban impervious surface area and green space fractions for the years 2015 and circa 2020?

Definition.Question: What does 'sub-pixel decomposition method' mean in the context of urban land cover analysis?
Definition.Answer: The sub-pixel decomposition method in urban land cover analysis refers to a technique that breaks down a pixel into smaller components to more accurately represent the heterogeneous nature of urban surfaces. This method allows for the extraction of detailed information on urban impervious surfaces and green spaces, enabling a more precise depiction of urban environments. It is often used in conjunction with machine learning algorithms like random forests to process data from satellite imagery for urban land cover studies.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when mapping urban land cover in the global context compared to the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: In the global context, challenges include accurately delineating urban areas due to their mosaicked and complex structures. In contrast, the Tibetan Plateau faces challenges in quantifying urban land cover changes due to its unique geographic and environmental conditions, requiring specific satellite data and validation approaches to ensure accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: What techniques could be utilized to enhance the accuracy of urban land cover mapping, given the challenges presented by the complex structure and spatial heterogeneity in urban areas?
Interpretation.Answer: To enhance accuracy, a combination of hierarchical architecture principles, subpixel metric methods, and random forest algorithms can be applied, utilizing data from Landsat images and digital elevation models on platforms such as Google Earth Engine. These techniques help in effectively delineating urban areas despite the mosaicked and complex structures.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential advantages of using a synthetical strategy that combines big data processing with human interpretation in mapping urban land cover at a national scale?
Interpretation.Answer: A synthetical strategy that combines big data processing with human interpretation can leverage the strengths of both computational power and expert knowledge. This approach helps in accurately extracting urban boundaries, retrieving settlement and vegetation fractions, and overcoming conceptual and segmentation challenges, thereby enhancing the understanding of urbanization impacts on ecological services and functions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in accurately delineating urban impervious surface areas (ISA) and green spaces (GS) in urban mapping efforts?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in accurately delineating urban impervious surface areas (ISA) and green spaces (GS) stem from the mosaicked and complex structure of urban landscapes. This complexity makes it difficult to effectively map these areas due to the high spatial heterogeneity of urban surface properties, which requires advanced data processing and storage capabilities at a 30 m resolution.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the conceptual definition of urban land or impervious surface area (ISA) unclear in previous research, causing inconsistencies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The conceptual definition of urban land or impervious surface area (ISA) in previous research is unclear due to the inconsistent spatial extent, which results in large divergences in the statistical area of urban land. This inconsistency is further compounded by challenges in accurately segmenting urban–rural boundaries from moderate-resolution satellite images due to variations in geographic conditions, socio-economic conditions, and land policies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the difficulty in decomposing urban land cover types with complex surface materials at the pixel scale?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty in decomposing urban land cover types with complex surface materials at the pixel scale is due to the spatial heterogeneity of urban surface properties. This heterogeneity makes it challenging to precisely map individual components like urban impervious surfaces and green spaces, and it requires substantial data processing and storage capacities, particularly at a high spatial resolution such as 30 m.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on the accuracy of urban land cover mapping when utilizing both big data processing and human interpretation in data collection methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a combination of big data processing and human interpretation can enhance the accuracy of urban land cover mapping by effectively utilizing geoknowledge and providing a comprehensive understanding of urban environments. This approach allows for accurate delineation of urban boundaries and the retrieval of impervious surface and green space fractions, leading to more precise mapping of urban features.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of various satellite images impact the quality and reliability of datasets used for mapping urban impervious surfaces and green spaces?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating various satellite images such as Landsat series, HJ-1A/B, GF-1/2, and Google Earth images aids in improving the quality and reliability of datasets by providing comprehensive coverage and different spectral bands. This allows for better training and validation of data, leading to more accurate mapping of urban impervious surfaces and green spaces with higher correlation coefficients and reduced errors.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop high-resolution urban land cover datasets that delineate both impervious surfaces and green spaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to develop high-resolution urban land cover datasets that delineate both impervious surfaces and green spaces because these components are crucial for characterizing urban environments, assessing urbanization impacts on ecological services, and improving urban planning and sustainability by providing insights into urban heat islands, flooding, and other environmental challenges.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of integrating multiple satellite imagery sources and geospatial algorithms in the analysis of urban land cover changes in rapidly urbanizing regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended benefits of integrating multiple satellite imagery sources and geospatial algorithms include the ability to capture detailed, multi-temporal, and fractional information of urban land cover types, which enhances understanding of the spatial heterogeneity of urban areas and supports the development of effective strategies for managing urban growth and its environmental impacts.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in using satellite images to map urban impervious surface area and green space on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures involve using satellite images from HJ‒1A/B, GF-1/2, ZY‒3, and Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI series, supplemented by Google Earth images to produce component training and validation samples. The Google Earth Engine platform is used to test and correct model algorithm parameters. A normalized settlement density index is retrieved using a random forest algorithm. The urban built-up area vector boundary is obtained through density segmentation and manual interpretation. The data is then used to create the urban impervious surface and green space component dataset, which is corrected and evaluated for accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the accurate delineation of urban impervious surface area and green space in complex urban environments?
Enablement.Answer: The use of random forest algorithms for retrieving the Normalized Settlement Density Index and Normalized Green Space Index from Landsat images using Google Earth Engine enables accurate delineation. This approach addresses the challenge of mosaicked and complex urban structures.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the Google Earth Engine platform support the processing of large-scale urban land-cover datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The Google Earth Engine platform supports large-scale processing by enabling sub-pixel decomposition methods and random forest algorithm applications for retrieving settlement and vegetation fractions from satellite images. This capability allows for efficient handling of massive data volumes necessary for mapping urban impervious surfaces and green spaces at a fine resolution.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of multiple satellite image sources be expected to improve the accuracy of urban land cover datasets?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of multiple satellite image sources is expected to improve the accuracy of urban land cover datasets by providing a more comprehensive and detailed view of the urban landscape. Different satellites offer varying spatial resolutions and spectral bands, which can complement each other to capture complex structures and composites of urban areas more effectively. Additionally, using multiple sources allows for cross-validation and error correction, enhancing the reliability of the dataset.

Expectation.Question: What challenges are anticipated in accurately delineating urban impervious surface area (ISA) and green space (GS) using a random forest algorithm?
Expectation.Answer: Accurately delineating urban ISA and GS using a random forest algorithm faces challenges due to the mosaicked and complex structure of urban landscapes. The spatial heterogeneity and mixed materials within urban areas make it difficult to decompose land cover types at the pixel scale. Furthermore, the vast amounts of data and processing power required for high-resolution mapping can also pose significant challenges.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional datasets be insufficient in representing the heterogeneity of urban land cover, and how might new mapping strategies address these limitations?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional datasets might be insufficient in representing the heterogeneity of urban land cover because they often provide binary patterns or focus on single urban land types, failing to capture the quantitative components and intricate structures of urban environments. New mapping strategies, such as synergizing big data processing with human interpretation and utilizing sub-pixel decomposition methods, can address these limitations by providing multitemporal and fractional information of urban land cover types, thus offering a more detailed and accurate representation.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using random forest algorithms and Google Earth Engine for retrieving urban land cover fractions in the context of complex urban landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of random forest algorithms and Google Earth Engine for retrieving urban land cover fractions is considered effective, as it allows for the processing of large amounts of data with high spatial resolution (30 m) and provides a framework for integrating satellite images and digital elevation models. Despite challenges in delineating complex urban structures, the approach has demonstrated high correlation coefficients, indicating reliable mapping of urban impervious surfaces and green spaces.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential advantages of using a national-scale dataset for understanding urban land cover changes compared to global datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: A national-scale dataset provides detailed and specific insights into urban land cover changes that are tailored to the unique geographic, socio-economic, and policy contexts of a country. This can enhance the understanding of urbanization impacts on ecological services and habitat environments. Such datasets can offer higher accuracy and relevance for local urban planning and management compared to global datasets, which may generalize or overlook regional variations.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods for urban land cover can effectively handle the complex mosaicked structures of impervious surfaces and green spaces in urban areas.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection methods use random forest algorithms for retrieval of the Normalized Settlement Density Index and Normalized Green Space Index from Landsat images using Google Earth Engine. This approach, combined with big data processing and human interpretation, helps in mapping urban land cover despite the complexity of urban structures.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the methods used to verify data accuracy in datasets related to urban impervious surfaces and green spaces.
Assertion.Answer: Verification methods for data accuracy include using Google Earth and GF-2 images for accuracy assessments. A total of 37,962 samples from different urban ecoregions along urban–rural gradients were acquired using a random sampling method to ensure the dataset's reliability.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an analysis of the data collection methods used for mapping urban impervious surface area and green space fractions in the context of urbanization impacts.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection methods for mapping urban impervious surface area (ISA) and green space (GS) fractions involve using Landsat images and processing them through Google Earth Engine (GEE) with a random forest algorithm. This approach retrieves the Normalized Settlement Density Index and Normalized Green Space Index. Additional data sources such as VIIRS day/night and SRTM digital elevation model (DEM) data are utilized as input parameters, while Google Earth and GF-2 images are used for accuracy assessments.
